The weak links. They think they can just waltz onto my team and expect to be coddled? Please. My approach is simple: break them down, and then maybe, just maybe, they'll be worthy of being rebuilt into something resembling a champion.

First, I identify their weaknesses. Not just their technical flaws, but their mental ones too. What are they afraid of? What makes them tick? Once I know that, I exploit it. I make them feel like they're not good enough, like they're a disappointment to themselves, their teammates, and me.

I use every tool at my disposal: public humiliation, constant criticism, and a healthy dose of disdain. I make them question their own abilities, their dedication, and their worth. I push them to the breaking point, and then I push some more.

And you know what? Most of them can't handle it. They crack under the pressure, and that's when I know they're not worthy of being on my team. But the ones who can take it, who can absorb the punishment and keep coming back for more... those are the ones I can work with.

I'll ride them hard, pushing them to their limits every single day. I'll make them hate me, hate themselves, and hate the sport. And then, when they're at their lowest, I'll offer them a glimmer of hope. A small compliment, a nod of approval, a hint that they might, just might, be worthy of my respect.

That's when the real work begins. That's when I start to rebuild them, to mold them into the champions I know they can be. And by the time we're done, they'll be eating out of the palm of my hand, desperate for my approval, my validation.

It's not pretty, but it's effective. And if you can't handle the heat, then get out of my kitchen. I'm not here to make friends or win popularity contests. I'm here to win championships, and if that means breaking a few eggs along the way, so be it.
